HOW DO I USE QUICK PLAY?

Quick Play is currently an experimental feature. Follow these steps to use it:

  1. To enable it, click ‘Settings’ in the lower left corner of the Launcher.
  2. On the Settings page, scroll down to the ‘Experimental Features’ section, and toggle the ‘Enable Experimental Quick Play Feature’ option.
  3. Once enabled, navigate to the Minecraft: Java Edition section of the Launcher. A new ‘Quick Play’ bar will now be visible in the Launcher’s upper right corner.
  4. Within that bar, select ‘Quick Play’ to expand the bar.
  5. Your five most recently played Java Edition worlds will appear in a list. Click one to jump directly into that world from the Launcher!

FAQ: 

What do I have to do to make the new Home Page show up in my Launcher?  

  • Just turn on the Home Page option from within your Launcher’s “General” Settings section and it should appear, replacing the “News” section in the Launcher’s left hand navigation with "Home".  

How do I enable this feature in Launcher Settings? 

  • In your Launcher, click “Settings” at the bottom left of the screen. Then, on the Launcher’s “General” Setting page, scroll down to the bottom to find the new “Experimental Features” section. Toggle the “Enable HomePage” on.  

Does this impact any of my worlds or any of my current game saves? 

  • No, it’s just a new, better way to approach using the Launcher.

I’ll start with what I personally liked the top part of the screen with the quick play features are nice but could be a little bigger/Bolder. If the articles are going to have a short description under the thumbnail it should be its own separate summary rather then just the beginning text of the article it would just be more visually appealing without them in my opinion. Snapshots and previews should be separated from other Minecraft News and articles since right now they clutter the bottom part of the launcher and a clear distinction between a snapshot/preview article and a Minecraft news/community one. Now as for my suggested features. A Community page or forums would be a nice addition similar to minecraft chinas Launcher. Minecraft could use a nice place to interact and see what’s trending in the game. A place with direct access to the feedback page. Server list with top/featured servers. Weekly showcases of minecraft art/ community creations would also be super fun and cool. The Launcher could be a nice platform for the minecraft community but I know the implications that comes with and how difficult it could be to implement. Glad to see your guys are thinking about updating the launcher hope to see more!

Just checked out this new launcher page - it looks great! However, there are some ideas I suggest you look into:

  1. The centered layout of the Quick Play / Play Minecraft buttons is great and brand new. However, these buttons are way too small compared to the rest of the home page. The text in the version button is barely readable. It needs to be upsized.
  2. The font has been the same, shifted off from the Java/Bedrock pages, but I think it would be a great time to use a more Minecraft-y font in some more places. Currently it's only used for large titles, but it should be used at least a bit more.
  3. The new sidebar showing more news needs a lot of work. The description texts need to be much smaller so that the entire description is visible. And it has to be centered - it's currently at the top of the box and isn't as visually pleasing.
  4. Add more animations! When shifting from one sidebar news to another, make the news at least slide from one to another, or even fade. It's abrupt when it moves from one to another so suddenly.
  5. Last, rename Minecraft for Windows into Minecraft: Bedrock Edition. It makes no sense - we have three more playable Minecraft games in Windows, and it will also fit in nicely with Minecraft: Java Edition.

Now, as for my suggested features, it would be great if you added tabs for easier, direct access to the Minecraft Feedback Website (feedback.minecraft.net), Bug Report Website (bugs.minecraft.net), and Help Center (help.minecraft.net). This may be enough.

1. Fix Blurry Images: Ensure that all images within the launcher, such as game thumbnails or background images, are of high quality and optimized for display.

  2. Cleaner Layout:

    • Consider redesigning the launcher interface to have a cleaner layout, possibly by simplifying the navigation menu or organizing content into more intuitive categories.
    • Provide options to customize the layout based on user preferences, such as hiding certain elements or rearranging the interface.

  3. Hide Sidebar via Button: Introduce a toggle button or gesture control to hide or show the sidebar in the launcher, giving users the flexibility to focus on the main content when desired.

  4. Adjust Elements:

    • Lower the position of elements like the news feed and search bar to create a more balanced and visually appealing layout.
    • Ensure that essential elements, such as the game launch buttons, remain easily accessible and prominent.

  5. Enlarge Banner Image: Increase the size of the banner image at the top of the launcher to make it more visually impactful and immersive for users.

  6. Animated Banner: Implement subtle animations or dynamic elements into the banner area to enhance its visual appeal and create an engaging user experience. This could include animated backgrounds, transition effects, or interactive elements that respond to user interactions.

The Sidebar Looks Out Of Place, And Laying Them Out Horizontally Would Make Them And The Text Box To Of Left Of Them Look More Natural And Pleasing. This Might Leave To Little Room For The Cycling Images Vertically, However. In Event It Does, Aligning Them To The Left Next To The Text Box Would Be A Much Better Option. With It's Current Spot, The Text Change Is A Little Too Subtle.

The Article Images Are Far Too Low Resolution To Take Up As Much Space As They Do, And With How Much Of The Screen Sits There Looking Blurry, I Find It Hard To Even Look At. (of course, this issue largely easy to fix moving forward, so i hope it will be.)

I Think It Would Do Well To Seperate Patch Notes And News Into Their Own Seperate Categories, As Well.

 

In My Humble UI Design-Loving Opinion, It's Jank, It's Bloated, And I Don't Like It. 5/10.

Hope I'll Be Able To Keep In Off In The Future.

Bedrock does not have the same feature, so if you update and you can't or don't want to play on the newest version, you can't change back. It would help users with low-end hardware, and let you choose your favourite version of the game.

If we have to choose, I believe these would be  the best old-version candidates for Bedrock Edition (using Java's update names/IDs):

Beta 1.7 speaks for itself. Arguably the closure of Classic Minecraft, Beta 1.8 significantly altered terrain and gameplay, effectively closing a chapter in Minecraft history. Many would love to be able to enjoy the strange classic magic of Beta pre-1.8!

Any of 1.0 to 1.6 As these were official releases before the major changes of 1.7.

1.7 Incredibly popular to date, this wasn't the "Update that Changed the World" for no reason. This added a host of biomes &  generation additions, items, blocks, etc and was the last version before oceans and the underground were changed by Monuments and the three minerals (Granite, etc)

1.12 Because this was the last major update to Minecraft, anothe favorite, before the most recent "overhaul" updates (Aquatic, Village, Nether), which have more or less upgraded Minecraft to an entirely other kind of experience.

1.13, 1.14, 1.15 and the rest of what I call the "overhaul" or "Minecraft 2.0" updates, are each so monumental all by themselves as well as being among the most recent.

Finally, having even just the final states of each of the next updates to come (1.18, 1.19, etc) would really place enormous customization and freedom in Bedrock players' hands, something we've wanted and Java has enjoyed for a while.

Personal top 5: 

Beta (pre-1.8)
1.0
1.12
1.17
1.18 and beyond

As for the whole "modified installation" warning? I was modding this game and manually compiling my own modpacks back before modpacks were even a blip on the radar; and when minecraft mods in general barely even existed in the first place.

Take these ineffective and absurd "warnings" and get rid of them. Or at the very least give those of us who know what we're doing an option to COMPLETELY disable them.

As jaded as this may be, I'd be surprised to see them take this suggestion. If memory serves, there are new telemetry features in the latest version of Minecraft, and that telemetry data is valuable, both monetarily, and ostensibly for fixing bugs.

Hear me out, instead of adding the option to remove them, they allowed you to turn it off on only certain modified/old versions of Minecraft, for use in installations without the warning, without turning them all off?

If warning people about these versions is really such a concern, maybe hide the option to disable them inside launcher_settings.json or something. That way in order to use the option, someone would either need to already know about it, or go out of their way to look it up online.
absolutely. i don't don't know why, but the little warning label bugs me a lot.

I almost exclusively play Modded Java Edition (Usually Forge), and actively try to use the official ("vanilla") launcher for proper account verification.  I have two arguments as to why these warnings are more harmful than helpful.

1) The boy who cried wolf.  I trust modded instances.  With every new instance getting an obnoxious pop-up and then a perpetual warning icon, I am being trained to ignore the launcher's warnings.

2) The obnoxiousness, especially by that pop-up, will drive people to use 3rd party launchers which bypass the vanilla launcher entirely.  I believe that is far riskier than what the pop-up is warning about.

My suggestions would be:

1) Change the warning icon into a beneficial feature.  Allow the mods adding 'versions' to the launcher to define their own icon so players can see at a glance what kind of modification is used in that instance.  Add a boarder so they can't just use a blank icon to hide their modded status.

I agree in bringing back the tutorial worlds. The game, to me, doesn't set new or returning players up for success without aid of external guides.

Tutorial worlds gave new or returning players a space to learn and use new features from an update, but also features which have changed since last playing and to become exposed to all of the key features of minecraft in an interactive manner. When I was a new player on Console editions, the pop-up dialogue tutorials and all the necessary resources being nearby allowed me to experiment with brewing, trading, Redstone, building a nether portal, and other features that are considered mid or late game.
The builds that the developers make in these worlds can also inspire builds that players may attempt in their own survival world.

An example of a feature that many players use, but is not fundamentally taught in-game, is building a nether portal. Currently, new players need to explore a world and find a broken nether portal and deduce the basic shape of the portal, that there are other dimensions, that gold is important/common in said dimension, and that the portal must be lit with an included flint and steel.
To figure out all these things seems less likely than said new player thinking, "this is a weird and cool structure." This will probably lead the player to find external tutorials on the nether portal. A tutorial world can solve this issue by having a tutorial for players to learn in-game.

These are my thoughts anyways.
